section.name: EURO ART & CIV > 1400: RENAISSANCE TO CONTEMP

comments:
This course serves as an introduction to traditional forms of visual arts including painting, sculpture, print culture, along with new media such as photography, film, performance and installation art. Covering European and American art from 1400 to the present, it offers a broad historical overview of key movements and figures. Lectures and readings investigate the major themes and contexts involved in visual art production after the Middle Ages.

The majority of students felt that this was an “excellent” introductory course, with high praise coming from novices to the subject matter. Students had high praise for lectures, which were hailed as “highly engaging” and “incredibly interesting,” and most – though not all – felt the material stimulated their interest in art history.

Professor Silver garnered favorable comments, and was called a “subject matter expert” and a wonderful instructor. Declaring that Professor Silver “made the course,” one student described him as “on topic, commanding and interesting.” Though some students felt that some of the material was at times rushed, most felt that the class moved at a steady pace that allowed for adequate discussion and in-depth analysis. He was commended for his knowledgeable presentations and his enthusiasm, which provided students with “insightful analyses.” Further, students noted that he always encouraged questions both in and out of the class.

Most students walked away from the course recommending it to majors and non-majors alike, and were pleased with the survey course’s ability to cover a wealth of material over a relatively short period of time. Some students felt that the reading workload was too heavy, and that the material in readings was not thoroughly incorporated into lecture and recitation. However, others felt that while the readings could be dense, they were “very informative and essential to do well on the papers and tests.” The structure of tests called for rigorous studying, but most students felt the work was manageable.

section.name: EURO ART & CIV > 1400: RENAISSANCE TO CONTEMP

comments:
This course serves as an introduction to traditional forms of visual arts including painting, sculpture, print culture, along with new media such as photography, film, performance and installation art. Covering European and American art from 1400 to the present, it offers a broad historical overview of key movements and figures. Lectures and readings investigate the major themes and contexts involved in visual art production after the Middle Ages.

The majority of students felt that this was an “excellent” introductory course, with high praise coming from novices to the subject matter. Students had high praise for lectures, which were hailed as “highly engaging” and “incredibly interesting,” and most – though not all – felt the material stimulated their interest in art history.

Students felt that Professor Dombrowski, who taught the second half of the course focusing on modern art, was less effective in explaining the material than the first half’s professor, Professor Silver. However, they also noted that this was the “more difficult half of the course.” Further, he was credited as an exciting and highly knowledgeable instructor, and he was still well liked despite the density of his lectures.

Most students walked away from the course recommending it to majors and non-majors alike, and were pleased with the survey course’s ability to cover a wealth of material over a relatively short period of time. Some students felt that the reading workload was too heavy, and that the material in readings was not thoroughly incorporated into lecture and recitation. However, others felt that while the readings could be dense, they were “very informative and essential to do well on the papers and tests.” The structure of tests called for rigorous studying, but most students felt the work was manageable.

This course covers the great epochs of art and their relation to corresponding phases of Western political and sociological history. This class is designed for students who desire an introduction to the arts as well as for those who seek a foundation for more specialized study in the field.   Students loved this course. They reported that it was “an excellent overview for someone who has never taken an art history class before.” Students generally thought that the class was thought-provoking and enjoyable. Students also mentioned that the readings were very interesting.   Students generally agreed that Professor Clericuzio was great. They reported that Professor Clericuzio was organized, knowledgeable, and articulate.   Several students thought that Professor Clericuzio could have given them more of a “heads up” prior to assignments. Some students also reported that there was too much material covered. Some complained that the exam format did not allow room to show the professor what they had really mastered. However, students did report that Professor Clericuzio was always quick to respond to emails and questions.  This review is based on the 5 student comments that were submitted.
